subject: Last Call for Clarion
event:
Applications for the 2010 Clarion Writer's Workshop in San Diego close on March 1... so if you've been thinking of applying, now's the time to get your act together.

I will be one of the instructors at this year's Clarion.  

The good folks at the workshop sayeth:

"Clarion is widely recognized as a premier training ground for aspiring writers of fantasy and science fiction short stories. Many graduates have become well-known writers, and a large number have won major awards. Instructors are among the most respected writers and editors working in the field today. The 2010 writers in residence are Delia Sherman, George R.R. Martin, Dale Bailey, Samuel R. Delany, Jeff VanderMeer and Ann VanderMeer.

"The six-week workshop is held on the beautiful beachside campus of the University of California, San Diego.  Since its inception in 1968, Clarion has been known as the “boot camp” for writers of speculative fiction. Each year 18 students, ranging in age from late teens to those in mid-career, are selected from applicants who have the potential for highly successful writing careers. Students are expected to write several new short stories during the six-week workshop, and to give and receive constructive criticism. Instructors and students reside together in campus apartments throughout the intensive six-week program.
 
The application period for the 2010 workshop ends on March 1. Applicants must submit two short stories with their application. Scholarships are available. Additional information can be found at http://clarion.ucsd.edu."

comments.article: Already applied.

Hey GGRM, I'm a longtime reader and an unpublished writer. Any idea yet if you will be teaching at Clarion next year? I can't apply this year because I'm a minor, but I definitely plan on applying for the 2011 workshop.
Afraid not.  Clarion has a different lineup of instructors every year.  I may teach again one day, but probably not for a few years.

I've been working diligently for months! I'm afraid I'm just too much of a perfectionist - I can't write a story without taking a hatchet to it afterwards. Besides, when I found out about the workshop, I had literally just decided to start writing so I didn't have any corpus of material built up; just piles of concepts.

I hope to see you there!

comments.article:
I always get my knuckles rapped for not taking holidays by my boss, and so I could easily take six weeks off. I don't think that I will apply though on the pure number aspect of it.

There is about 8000 people reading this journal, even if only 1 % applied that is 80 for 18 places. Assuming that all the other people are attending also have 80 people interested, plus other advertisement places (disregarded), Then the chances of success woulf only be 3% (providing that you and all other candidates measure up to each other). The risk is just too high to spend €50 on, especially when you don't now where it is going. I can see why they need it, otherwise instead of 80 applying from this page, then 800 may apply.

For those that applied, good luck as the risk could get a huge reward.

I would love to apply.

But unfortunately I only write in German. Any chance we could do the whole workshop in German?

Maybe some day my English will be good enough to write stories in it but I fear this day is quite some time ahead.
comments.subject: CLARION

comments.article: I really, really wish I could... but I've just started a new job and I'm living in the UK right now.

I wish, i wish. This year, my Mr. is away doing Army stuff, and i can't see packing along two young children and a cantankerous bulldog, even if i could get accepted. It might be funny, but i doubt productive. For anyone.

For all those of us that can't go, though, there are still some great books about writing out by some great writers, and we can still try to get a few short stories done in the time-frame. Kind of like following along in independent study. Not having the scratch or the time to go to the great confences and classes doesn't have to stop us from writing and studying. All those fantasic writers were once unpublished, unrecognised scribblers, too. They got there from here, at one point in time. Clarion would be excellent, but you can be excellent in your living room, too.
Waiting on pins and needles to hear if I've been accepted... this is absolutely maddening, I tell you.
